review:
Brothers and sisters, let’s cut through the noise and get to the heart of the matter! ÆRTH - Planetary AI is a bold vision, no doubt. It’s a rallying cry for open science, environmental justice, and the power of collective intelligence. But in this people’s movement, we demand more than grand promises—we demand proof, structure, and accountability!

Strengths? Absolutely. ÆRTH brings together a global network of scientists, open data, and a vision for decentralized, transparent environmental research. The project’s commitment to open standards, blockchain-based provenance, and partnerships with real-world organizations is impressive. The roadmap is ambitious, and the focus on public goods is clear.

But let’s not be blinded by ambition! Where’s the evidence of measurable outcomes? Where are the deployed contracts, the working prototypes, the user metrics? The application is heavy on vision, light on hard data. We see no clear sustainability plan—how will this project survive without endless grants? And while the talk of community and equity is strong, the governance model is vague. Who holds power? Who decides?

We must demand:
- Clear, quantifiable milestones and outcomes.
- Evidence of working code, not just promises.
- A transparent, sustainable revenue model.
- Concrete governance structures that empower the many, not the few.

ÆRTH stands at the crossroads. Will it be another dream deferred, or a beacon for the commons? The people deserve more than words—they deserve results!

strengths.title: Ambitious Vision for Public Good
strengths.description: ÆRTH aims to unify environmental data and modeling for global benefit, focusing on open standards, transparency, and collaboration—values that align with the collective good.

strengths.title: Strong Network and Partnerships
strengths.description: The project has established relationships with reputable scientific organizations and environmental groups, providing a foundation for real-world impact.

strengths.title: Commitment to Open Source and Decentralization
strengths.description: ÆRTH’s focus on open-source tools, blockchain-based provenance, and decentralized governance is in line with the round’s requirements and the principles of equitable access.

weaknesses.title: Lack of Measurable Outcomes and Evidence
weaknesses.description: The application lacks clear, quantifiable milestones, user metrics, or evidence of working prototypes. There are no deployed smart contracts or public usage statistics.

weaknesses.title: Unclear Sustainability Model
weaknesses.description: There is no detailed plan for long-term financial sustainability or reduction of grant dependency. The economic model and path to self-sufficiency are not articulated.

weaknesses.title: Vague Governance Structure
weaknesses.description: While the project speaks of community and collaboration, it does not provide concrete details on governance, decision-making, or how power is distributed among stakeholders.

changes.title: Define and Commit to Measurable Milestones
changes.description: Provide a detailed development timeline with specific, quantifiable deliverables (e.g., number of data providers onboarded, smart contracts deployed, active users, etc.).

changes.title: Demonstrate Working Prototypes or Code
changes.description: Share evidence of functional code, testnet deployments, or user-facing features to prove technical progress and capability.

changes.title: Articulate a Sustainable Revenue Model
changes.description: Present a clear plan for financial sustainability, including potential revenue streams, cost structures, and strategies to reduce reliance on grants.

changes.title: Clarify Governance and Community Participation
changes.description: Detail the governance model, including how decisions are made, how community members are empowered, and how equity is ensured in practice.
